questions.text: An elderly patient presenting with a large indirect inguinal hernia complains of scrotal pain. Which nerve is most likely being compressed by the hernial sac
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked structure B represents the Ilioinguinal nerve.

The ilioinguinal nerve runs within the inguinal canal and gives off the anterior scrotal nerve, which provides sensory innervation to the scrotum. Hence, compression of the anterior scrotal nerve would cause scrotal pain.

Ilioinguinal nerve:

  • The ilioinguinal nerve originates from the first lumbar ventral ramus. The ilioinguinal nerve pierces the aponeurosis of the external abdominal oblique proximal to the superficial inguinal ring or divides into terminal cutaneous branches within the inguinal canal.
  • Sensory branches innervate the skin of the proximal medial thigh and the skin over the root of the penis and proximal part of the scrotum in males (anterior scrotal nerve), or the skin covering the mons pubis and the adjoining labium majus in females (anterior labial nerve).
  • Lesions of the ilioinguinal nerve may be injured or entrapped during inguinal surgery, particularly for inguinal hernia repair, leading to sensory disturbances including pain from the external genitalia and proximal medial thigh.

questions.text: A 45-year-old porter develops a direct inguinal hernia. If the hernia extended through the superficial inguinal ring, it would be surrounded by all of the abdominal wall layers EXCEPT the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Direct inguinal hernia is covered only by the transversalis fascia and external spermatic fascia

Direct inguinal hernia :

  • Direct inguinal hernias result from weakness in the posterior wall of the inguinal canal in Hesselbach's triangle. Direct hernias lie medial to the inferior epigastric vessels.
  • Direct inguinal hernia is covered only by the transversalis fascia and external spermatic fascia, as it protrudes outside the spermatic cord's internal spermatic fascia.

Indirect inguinal hernia :

  • An indirect inguinal hernia arises through the deep inguinal ring lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels.
  • Indirect hernias are related to the abnormal persistence of a patent processus vaginalis. Indirect hernias do not protrude beyond the inguinal canal and are covered by the same layers as the spermatic cord: namely, the internal spermatic fascia, cremaster and external spermatic fascia.

choices.text: Just outside the superficial inguinal ring

questions.text: A paediatrician has diagnosed a newborn baby with right-sided cryptorchidism. The testis may have been trapped in any site except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Descent of testis :

  • The testis begins development as a retroperitoneal structure in the posterior abdominal wall.
  • The testis is attached to the anterolateral abdominal wall by the gubernaculum. The gubernaculum undergoes relative shortening, resulting in the dragging of the testis downwards into the pelvis.
  • Testis starts developing at week 7 (2nd month) and reaches the pelvic cavity(iliac fossa) by the 3rd month.
  • Testis lies at the site of the deep inguinal ring up to the 7th month of intrauterine life. They pass along the inguinal canal during the 7th month.
  • Finally, the testis reaches the base of the scrotum at birth (9th month).

Cryptorchidism:

Failure of the testis to descend to the scrotum results in an undescended testis, also known as cryptorchidism.

Possible arrest sites can be the deep inguinal ring (Option A), the inguinal canal, the superficial inguinal ring (Option B), at the pelvic brim (Option C), and the iliac fossa.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the ER with a large bowel obstruction resulting from a left-sided indirect inguinal hernia. The most likely intestinal segment involved in this obstruction is the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The sigmoid colon is the most likely intestinal segment to be involved in a left-sided indirect inguinal hernia.

The sigmoid colon is a highly mobile, intraperitoneal portion of the left colon that can easily herniate through the inguinal canal.

Explanation of other options :

Terminal ileum (Option B): Terminal ileum is unlikely because while it's mobile, it's a small bowel and is more characteristic of right-sided hernias.

Descending colon (Option C): The Descending colon is fixed retroperitoneally and cannot herniate.

Rectum (Option D): Rectum is a structure in the pelvis; it is too inferior to enter the deep inguinal ring and causes an indirect inguinal hernia.

choices.text: Lateral border of rectus abdominus muscle

questions.text: The boundaries of the inguinal triangle include all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The inguinal triangle (Hesselbach's triangle) is the site for direct inguinal hernias and is formed by :

  • Medially by the lateral border of the rectus abdominis
  • Inferiorly by the inguinal ligament
  • Superiorly by the inferior epigastric artery

questions.text: The superficial inguinal ring is an opening in which structure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The superficial inguinal ring is a slit-like opening between the diagonal fibres of the external abdominal oblique.

Superficial inguinal ring :

  • The superficial (external) inguinal ring is the end of the inguinal canal and is superior to the pubic tubercle.
  • It is a triangular opening in the aponeurosis of the external oblique, with its apex pointing superolateral and its base formed by the pubic crest.
  • The two remaining sides of the triangle (the medial crus and the lateral crus) are attached to the pubic symphysis and the pubic tubercle, respectively.
  • At the apex of the triangle, the two crura are held together by crossing (intercrural) fibres, which prevent further widening of the superficial ring.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with a gradually enlarging scrotal swelling, which appears during heavy weight lifting and disappears when lying down. On examination, the swelling is reducible and extends from the inguinal canal into the scrotum. Which type of hernia is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • An indirect inguinal hernia protrudes through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal in Hesselbach's triangle.
  • The protruding peritoneal sac enters the inguinal canal by passing through the deep inguinal ring, just lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels. The extent of its excursion down the inguinal canal depends on the amount of processus vaginalis that remains patent.
  • If the entire processus vaginalis remains patent, the peritoneal sac may traverse the length of the canal, exit the superficial inguinal ring, and continue into the scrotum. ;

Explanation of other options :

Direct inguinal hernia (Option A): A direct inguinal hernia does not traverse the entire length of the inguinal canal but may exit through the superficial inguinal ring. When this occurs, the peritoneal sac acquires a layer of external spermatic fascia and can extend, like an indirect hernia, into the scrotum.

Femoral hernia (Option C): A femoral hernia is a protrusion of abdominal viscera through the femoral ring into the femoral canal. It appears as a mass in the femoral triangle, inferolateral to the pubic tubercle.

Obturator hernia (Option D): An obturator hernia is a protrusion of a loop of bowel through the obturator canal.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with a right groin swelling, identified as an inguinal hernia. During hernia repair, the surgeon encounters all the below-mentioned structures within the inguinal canal except :
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The cremasteric nerve is not a content of the inguinal canal, while the cremasteric artery and vein are contents of the inguinal canal in men.

Inguinal canal :

  • The inguinal canal is a slit-like passage that extends in a downward and medial direction, just above and parallel to the lower half of the inguinal ligament.
  • It begins at the deep inguinal ring and continues for approximately 4 cm, ending at the superficial inguinal ring.

Boundaries of the inguinal canal :

The walls of the inguinal canal are formed by different muscles and fascia :

  • Anterior wall - External oblique aponeurosis and internal oblique muscle
  • Posterior wall - Transversalis fascia and conjoined tendon (formed by internal oblique and transversus abdominis)
  • Roof - Arching fibres of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles
  • Floor - Inguinal ligament (a modification of external oblique aponeurosis)

Contents of the inguinal canal :

  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Spermatic cord in men
  • The round ligament of the uterus in females
  • Ilioinguinal nerve

The structures in the spermatic cord include:

  1. Ductus deferens
  2. Artery to the ductus deferens (from the inferior vesical artery)
  3. Testicular artery (from the abdominal aorta)
  4. Pampiniform plexus of veins (testicular veins)
  5. Cremasteric artery and vein
  6. Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve (innervation to the cremasteric muscle)
  7. Sympathetic and visceral afferent nerve fibres
  8. Lymphatics
  9. Remnants of the processus vaginalis.

choices.text: Inferior epigastric artery and lateral umbilical fold
Medial umbilical ligament and inferior epigastric artery

questions.text: During a laparoscopic examination of the deep surface of the lower anterior abdominal wall, the attending physician noted something of interest and asked the young resident to look at the medial inguinal fossa. To do so, the young doctor would have to look at the area between the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The medial inguinal fossa is an important anatomical landmark for understanding direct inguinal hernias. The medial inguinal fossa is a space on the inner abdominal wall between the medial umbilical fold and the lateral umbilical fold, through which direct hernias bulge.

Boundaries of the medial inguinal fossa :

  • Medial boundary: Medial umbilical ligament
  • Lateral boundary: Inferior epigastric artery

The medial umbilical fold is made by the medial umbilical ligament (the obliterated portion of the umbilical artery), while the lateral umbilical fold is a fold of peritoneum over the inferior epigastric vessels.

The median umbilical fold is a midline structure made by the median umbilical ligament (obliterated urachus).

The lateral inguinal fossa is a space lateral to the lateral umbilical fold. Indirect inguinal hernias push through the deep inguinal ring in this space.

questions.text: If one were to make an incision parallel to and 2 inches above the inguinal ligament, one would find the inferior epigastric vessels between which layers of the abdominal wall?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The inferior epigastric vessels lie on the inner surface of the transversus abdominis and are covered by the parietal peritoneum. Remember, the peritoneum lies over the inferior epigastric vessels to make the lateral umbilical fold. Camper's fascia and Scarpa's fascia are two layers of the superficial fascia - Camper's is the fatty layer and Scarpa's is the membranous layer.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man visits a surgeon after experiencing severe pain in the right lower quadrant while lifting a heavy cabinet. Examination revealed a tender reducible swelling above the inguinal ligament which increased in size while coughing. Surgery was indicated and during surgical exploration, a hernial sac was found lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels. Which type of hernia do these findings represent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • An inguinal hernia is the protrusion or passage of a peritoneal sac, with or without abdominal contents, through a weakened part of the abdominal wall in the groin.
  • It occurs because the peritoneal sac enters the inguinal canal either indirectly, through the deep inguinal ring or directly, through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal (Hesselbach's triangle).
  • Inguinal hernias are therefore classified as either indirect or direct.

questions.text: Which structure passes through the deep inguinal ring?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The round ligament of the uterus passes through the deep inguinal ring and runs through the inguinal canal. ;

Deep inguinal ring :

  • The deep inguinal ring is a defect in the transversalis fascia situated lateral to the inferior epigastric vessel.
  • In females, the round ligament of the uterus passes through the deep inguinal canal and traverses the inguinal canal.
  • The round ligament of the uterus is a derivative of the gubernaculum, a structure that pulls the gonads into place during embryonic development. In males, the scrotal ligament is what remains from the gubernaculum.
  • In males, the spermatic cord passes through the deep inguinal ring.

Explanation of other options:

Iliohypogastric nerve (Option A): Runs above the inguinal canal and exits through the superficial inguinal ring.

Inferior epigastric artery (Option C): Lies medial to the deep inguinal canal and does not pass through the ring.

Ilioinguinal nerve (Option B): The ilioinguinal nerve courses through the inguinal canal. It leaves through the superficial ring and gives off the anterior labial or scrotal branch as a cutaneous continuation. However, the ilioinguinal nerve does not pass through the deep ring - it enters the inguinal canal on the side.

questions.text: In a female with an indirect inguinal hernia, the herniated mass lies alongside which structure as it traverses the inguinal canal?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In females, the round ligament of the uterus is the main structure traversing the inguinal canal. In males, the most important structure in the inguinal canal is the spermatic cord.

Contents of inguinal canal :

  • Ilioinguinal nerve
  • Spermatic cord in males/Round ligament of the uterus in females
  • Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve

questions.text: Which nerve provides sensory innervation to the skin overlying mons pubis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The anterior labial nerve is the terminal branch of the ilioinguinal nerve which innervates skin overlying mons pubis in females.

Ilioinguinal nerve :

  • The ilioinguinal nerve provides motor and sensory innervation to the lower abdominal wall.
  • The motor branches of the ilioinguinal nerve supply the transversus abdominis and the internal abdominal oblique.
  • The ilioinguinal nerve extends into the inguinal canal, where its terminal branches provide sensory innervation to the genital region.
    • In females, these terminal branches are known as the anterior labial nerve, which supplies the labia majora.
    • In males, the equivalent branches are called the anterior scrotal nerve. (Option A) which is responsible for sensory innervation to the skin of the anterior scrotum in males.

Explanation of other options :

Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve (Option C): The femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve provides sensory innervation to the upper medial thigh.

Iliohypogastric nerve (Option D): Motor branches of the iliohypogastric nerve innervate the transversus abdominis and internal oblique muscle. While the cutaneous branches innervate the posterolateral gluteal and skin of the hypogastric region.

choices.text: Above the anterior superior iliac spine

questions.text: While demonstrating inguinal canal anatomy during the inguinal region dissection, you would indicate the position of the deep inguinal ring to be:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The deep inguinal ring is situated 1.25cm above the mid-inguinal point.

Deep inguinal ring :

  • A defect in the fascia transversalis.
  • Acts as the inlet of the inguinal canal.
  • Located superior and lateral to the mid-inguinal point.
  • The mid-inguinal point is the midpoint of a line drawn from the anterior superior iliac spine to the pubic symphysis. The femoral artery pulse can be palpated just below the mid-inguinal point.

Superficial inguinal ring :

  • Defect in the external oblique
  • Located above and medial to the pubic tubercle.
  • Acts as an outlet for the inguinal canal.

Midpoint of inguinal ligament: Refers to the midpoint of the line joining the anterior superior iliac spine and pubic tubercle.

Explanation of other options :

Above the pubic tubercle (Option C): The superficial inguinal ring is found above the pubic tubercle.

Supravesical fossa (Option D): It is the space between the median and medial umbilical fold.
